data.title: Robert Montague Coltrane (1872-1958)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Robert Coltrane born 1872 Hillsville, Carroll, Virginia, United States died 1958 Emory, Washington, Virginia, United States including ancestors + descendants + 2 photos + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 30 Dec 2023 | Created 4 Nov 2015

This page has been accessed 856 times.

Biography

Native Virginian

Descendant of Nancy Coltrane (1798-1873).

Robert was born in Hillsville, Virginia, then the family moved to Fancy Gap, Virginia. His father died when he was just 11 years old and from that age on, he supported his mother and siblings by running his father's grist mill. He wanted to follow his father's footsteps and attend VMI but had no formal education after his father's death. [1][2]

He went to a country school for five years, took the teacher's exam and studied law under his cousin, Judge David Bolen. He worked as a surveyor, lumberman, farmer and a Justice of the Peace.

He met his future wife, Bettie Sue Hines when both went to take the qualifying exam to teach school. She would ride in the sidecar of his motorbike. For Christmas, he gave her a book of poetry (photo attached); however, she was hoping for a silver dresser set. They married May 21, 1902 in Carroll County, Virginia.[3]They had four children:

Carlos Raymond Coltrane, b 1903

Virginia Catherine Coltrane, b 1906

Muriel Myrtle Coltrane, b 1912

William Branson Coltrane, b 1914

After their marriage, they moved to Mt Airy, North Carolina, and then Ivanhoe, Virginia, [4]Radford, Virginia[5] and Emory, Virginia where he lived until his death.

Robert loved history, especially the history of Southwest Virginia and some of his writings were featured in the columns of the Southwest Corner that appeared weekly in The Roanoke Times for more than 40 years. He was well-read, loved to work with his hands and there was never an arithmetic problem he could not solve.

Ad to sell logging equipment[6]

Namesake

Andrew Jackson Montague (1842-1862) entered Virginia Military Institute (VMI) in 1860 and was made drill master in 1861. He withdrew from college to join the Confederate Army in 1862 in Danville, Virginia. Andrew was wounded in the battle of Gaine's Mill (struck in the arm by a mini-ball) and died soon after from infection. He never married.

His brother, Edgar Burwell Montague also served in the same battalion as Branson, however, he survived the war and appears on the Apr. 24, 1865 list of paroled POW's. Edgar was a lawyer (before and after the War); Judge; Commonwealth Attorney for King and Queen Co. Va.; and merchant. Branson named his firstborn son, Robert Montague Coltrane after his friend.[7][8]
